content.title: SMA Embolism vs Thrombosis
content.definition: Clinical and angiographic differentiation between embolic and thrombotic occlusion of the superior mesenteric artery, which has important implications for treatment strategy.

concepts.definition: Acute occlusion from cardiac or proximal arterial embolus.

clinical_features.source: Atrial fibrillation (most common), LV thrombus, aortic plaque
clinical_features.location: Just distal to middle colic branch (tapered origin)
clinical_features.history: May have prior embolic events, cardiac history

concepts.definition: Occlusion from progressive atherosclerosis with superimposed thrombosis.

clinical_features.location: At or near SMA origin (ostial disease)
clinical_features.onset: May be preceded by chronic mesenteric ischemia symptoms
clinical_features.collaterals: Often well-developed from celiac and IMA
clinical_features.history: Food fear, weight loss, postprandial pain preceding acute event
clinical_features.multi_vessel: Often involvement of other mesenteric vessels

concepts.definition: Imaging features that distinguish embolic from thrombotic.

clinical_features.embolus: Meniscus sign, normal proximal SMA, abrupt cutoff
clinical_features.thrombus: Ostial occlusion, aortic calcification, collaterals visible
clinical_features.cta_findings: Both show SMA occlusion with wall enhancement of ischemic bowel

clinical_features.bypass: May be needed for thrombotic - address underlying stenosis
clinical_features.endovascular: Aspiration/thrombolysis for embolus, stent for thrombosis
clinical_features.anticoagulation: Long-term for embolic source, antiplatelet for atherosclerotic

sources.reference: Bala M et al. J Vasc Surg. 2017;65:1544-1557
Bjorck M et al. Eur J Vasc Endovasc Surg. 2017;53:460-510
